docs.lead_paragraph: In a reversal, the Bush administration has ruled that managed care organizations can limit and restrict coverage of emergency services for poor people on Medicaid. The new policy, disclosed in a recent letter to state Medicaid directors, appears to roll back standards established in a 1997 law and in rules issued by the Clinton administration in January 2001 and by the Bush administration itself in June 2002.

headline.main: STATES CAN LIMIT EMERGENCY ACCESS IN MEDICAID CASES

docs.abstract: Bush administration rules that states may place limits on coverage that health maintenance organizations provide for emergency services for poor people on Medicaid; 1997 law allowed states to require Medicaid recipients to enroll in HMO's, but provided certain safeguards for patients, including stipulation that HMO's had to provide coverage for Medicaid patients in any situation that 'prudent layperson' would regard as emergency; Sen Bob Graham, principal author of law, says removing this safeguard will undermine access to essential emergency services for low-income Americans and questions how administration can, by a letter, make such profound changes in policy established by statute; state officials, looking for ways to cut Medicaid costs, have discussed such restrictions as limiting number of emergency room visits that will be covered or requiring emergency rooms to get authorization from primary care doctor before treating Medicaid patient enrolled in state's managed care plan (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Saying rapid increases in malpractice premiums are driving doctors out of some states and pushing up the cost of health care, President Bush said today that a big part of the solution was to curb what he called frivolous suits and put a $250,000 limit on pain and suffering awards by juries in cases that go to trial. Mr. Bush called on Congress to enact national limits on the dollar amounts of jury awards in medical malpractice cases. His stance brought immediate condemnation from some Democrats, plaintiffs' lawyers and liberal interest groups. They said Mr. Bush was standing up for the interests of doctors and insurers at the expense of patients who receive shoddy care or worse.

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors in New Jersey are planning a work stoppage on Feb. 3 to protest rising malpractice insurance costs and to highlight their nearly yearlong demand for legislative relief. The job action, among a group of professionals who by nature are independent, would mean patients would have to postpone elective surgeries or other nonemergency procedures. While it is hard to predict how many of the state's 24,000 doctors will take part in the job action, some doctors say they will extend the job action for a week or longer.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new type of CT scan promoted as a means of detecting lung cancer at its earliest stages is unproven, can lead to invasive testing and would probably not be cost-effective as a widespread screening tool, researchers say. The so-called spiral CT scans view the lungs and surrounding tissue at various angles and can spot pea-sized growths, but they cost hundreds of dollars, are not covered by insurance, and may lead to more diagnostic procedures like surgery. Most people may want to hold off on getting the tests, researchers said in an analysis in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

docs.lead_paragraph: Angry about General Electric's decision to force employees to pay more for their health coverage, 17,000 workers at 48 locations in 23 states began a two-day nationwide strike today. At the G.E. lighting division complex here, more than 150 strikers picketed in the 20-degree weather to show G.E., the nation's most profitable company, that they would not accept such increases in out-of-pocket costs without a fight.

docs.lead_paragraph: Magellan Health Services is talking to its lenders about the possibility of filing for bankruptcy protection, the company said yesterday. Magellan, one of the nation's largest managed care companies in mental health, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was circulating a proposal with those lenders outlining a plan to restructure its debt. The company, which has about $1 billion in debt, said any bankruptcy filing would not affect its regular payments to hospitals, doctors, its employees or its customers. Under the proposal, $625 million of senior subordinated notes would be exchanged for ''substantially all of the equity of the company,'' according to the financial statements. The company's stock, which traded as high as $8.93 in April 2002, closed yesterday at 17 cents. Reed Abelson (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: Kentucky told the Supreme Court today that it should be allowed to guarantee patients a broader choice of doctors through a state law regulating managed care companies. Several justices indicated that they were inclined to uphold the 1994 law, which requires health maintenance organizations and other insurers to sign contracts with any provider willing to accept their payment rates and rules.

headline.main: State Argues for Broadening of Managed Care

docs.abstract: Kentucky argues before Supreme Court that it should not be bound by federal law that requires health maintenance organizations and other insurers to sign contracts with any provider willing to accept their payment rates and rules; says it should be allowed to guarantee patients broader choice of doctors through its 'any willing provider' law; Kentucky Assn of Health Plans, which brought appeal, argues that state law usurps power of federal government to regulate employee benefit plans and violates central tenet of managed care: that costs cannot be controlled unless HMO's limit number of doctors and hospitals participating in their provider networks; several justices appear inclined to uphold Kentucky law (M)
